title: 110_hr632
content:
The "H-Prize Act of 2007" defines key terms such as administering entity, Department of Energy, and Secretary of Energy. The Act also establishes prize authority. The Secretary will award cash prizes to advance hydrogen energy technologies through competitions advertised widely to encourage broad participation from various entities. Each competition will be announced through a notice in the Federal Register. The Secretary will award cash prizes for hydrogen energy technology advancements through competitions advertised in the Federal Register. A private entity will administer the competitions, including advertising, fundraising, and awarding prizes. The private entity will be responsible for developing criteria for selecting winners, determining prize amounts and funding sources, advising the Secretary on judge selection, and protecting participants' trade secrets in prize competitions. The Act allows for the withholding of trade secrets and confidential business information submitted by participants in competitive programs. Prizes will be funded by Federal appropriated funds and funds from the administering entity. The Secretary can also accept funds from other Federal agencies for cash prize programs. No special consideration can be given to private entities in exchange for donations. The Secretary can announce prize competitions under the Act until September 30, 2018, with funds needed for prizes to be appropriated or committed by the administering entity. Increases in prize amounts require notice and funding commitment. SEC. 4. PRIZE CATEGORIES. The Secretary will establish prizes for advancements in hydrogen technologies, prototypes of hydrogen-powered vehicles, and transformational changes in hydrogen production and distribution technologies. The Secretary will establish biennial awards for significant advances in hydrogen technologies, prototypes of hydrogen-powered vehicles, and transformational changes in hydrogen production and distribution technologies. Prizes may not exceed $1,000,000 each, and adjustments may be made if less than $4,000,000 is available for the competition. The Secretary will hold a biennial prize competition for prototypes and transformational technologies in hydrogen production and distribution. Prizes may not exceed $4,000,000 and will be awarded if participants meet performance criteria. The prize offered under this paragraph shall be a lump sum of $10,000,000 to the winner, with an additional match for each dollar of private funding raised for hydrogen technology. The match will be provided for 3 years or until the full prize amount is paid out. The winner can choose to have the match amount paid to another entity continuing the technology development. The Secretary will announce the rules for receiving the match in the notice required by section 3(b)(2). The prize will only be awarded when a registered participant meets the established criteria. The prize award under this paragraph is limited to $10,000,000 in Federal funds, with a goal of raising $40,000,000 for matching awards. Criteria for the prize will be established in consultation with various entities, including the Department's Hydrogen Technical and Fuel Cell Advisory Committee and other experts. The Secretary will assemble a panel of judges for each prize competition, including individuals from outside the Department and the private sector. Judges must not have personal or financial interests in participants or have relationships with participants. SEC. 5. ELIGIBILITY.

To win a prize under this Act, individuals or entities must comply with requirements in the Federal Register notice, be incorporated in the U.S. with a primary place of business, and not be a Federal entity or employee.

SEC. 6. INTELLECTUAL PROPERTY. The Federal Government will not claim intellectual property rights from participants in prize competitions under this Act. However, they can negotiate a license for the use of intellectual property developed for the competition. The Secretary may require registered participants to waive claims for any injury, death, damage, or loss arising from participation in a competition under this Act, except for willful misconduct. Liability insurance or financial responsibility is required in amounts determined by the Secretary. The Secretary may require registered participants to have liability insurance for claims by third parties for injury, death, or property damage resulting from competition activities. The Federal Government must be named as an additional insured under the insurance policy, and participants must agree to indemnify the Government against third party claims. SEC. 8. REPORT TO CONGRESS. The Secretary must report to Congress within 60 days of the first prize award, and annually after, identifying award recipients, describing their technologies, and detailing actions towards commercial application. SEC. 9. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. Authorization of Appropriations for fiscal years 2008 through 2017 includes $20,000,000 for awards in section 4(a)(1), $20,000,000 for awards in section 4(a)(2), and $10,000,000 for the award in section 4(a)(3). Additionally, $2,000,000 for administrative costs in fiscal years 2008 and 2009. Funds for prize awards under this Act remain available until expended. The funds authorized in this Act can be used until 10 fiscal years after the original appropriation, and can be transferred or reprogrammed for other purposes. No provision in this Act allows the use of funds in violation of the Anti-Deficiency Act. SEC. 10. NONSUBSTITUTION. The programs created under this Act are not a substitute for Federal research and development programs.
